string.value: Game Concepts
How To

If an ally goes to war, you will be given a notification; do you want to join your ally in its fight? If yes, your ally's enemy becomes your enemy. If no, then the alliance is broken. Allies can break from you if they don't want to join your fights.
Fighting in an alliance brings you clear numerical advantages. You do not have to battle alone against an enemy or an enemy alliance. However, you want to avoid alliance with any nation that seems weak or unlikely to defend your nation.
Participating in an alliance forces you to work within the constraints of an alliance. If you propose new alliances, your allies can reject them. Also, if you want to demand peace or offer surrender, you must first seek alliance approval.
Your allies are nations you've agreed to defend and vice versa. If you attack a nation, your allies are expected to join your fight. If your allies attack a nation, you are expected to join them.
Cede Occupied Territory

In a peace treaty with concessions, if you cede occupied territory, you are agreeing to surrender all enemy-occupied lands. If you're demanding concessions, then "cede occupied territory" means you're ordering your enemy to surrender regions that you occupy.
Declare Embargo
When you declare an embargo, all trade stops between your nation and the embargoed nation. When you go to war, trade automatically ceases between you and your enemy.
Declare War

A declaration of war creates a state of war. This cancels all trade between warring nations, and forces allied nations to join the war or break their alliances. To attack your new enemy, you must use the Operational map or Military policy panels to move forces.

In the Diplomacy panel you can review treaties and alliances. As the game progresses, you can impose embargos, declare war, demand surrender, or beg for peace. To view the diplomatic policy panel, click on the scroll icon in the upper right.
Grant Independence

You have the power to liberate nations. You can only grant independence when you own the region containing a nation's historic capital city. You cannot liberate regions you merely control (i.e., if you are at war with a nation, you cannot liberate the regions that you occupy). Any nation you liberate will automatically adopt your nation's ideology and ally with you.
Why grant independence? When you control regions that do not share your culture, their production is lowered. If you liberate a nation, its production rates improve. You decide if you want to control regions with reduced production or create a close ally with full production.
Install Friendly Government

As part of a peace treaty, you can demand or offer the installation of a friendly government. If you demand and your enemy agrees, then your enemy will change to your nation's ideology. If, in your peace treaty, you offer to switch your ideology and your enemy accepts, then your nation's ideology will change.
Military Access (Peace Treaty)

When proposing or accepting a peace treaty, military access allows you and your peace treaty partners to have military units in each others' regions. This is important because, without military access, your troops might resume fighting with enemy forces.
Military Access Treaty

This pact allows you to move forces into another nation's regions and vice versa. All alliance pacts include military access. If you do not belong to an alliance or have a military access pact, moving forces into another nation's regions is an act of war.
Peace Treaty

When you choose to end a war, you can propose peace to your enemy and/or enemy alliance. You can demand peace with enemy concessions, request peace with your concessions, or offer peace with no conditions.
Propose Alliance
When you propose an alliance treaty, you are promising to defend a nation, in exchange for its promise to defend you.
Ratified Agreements

These are agreements that you have with other nations. You can view ratified agreements at the bottom of the Diplomacy panel. Only Military Access agreements are on this list, as Alliance agreements appear separately, at the top of the Diplomacy panel.

Relations appear in each nation's panel, with a scale of 0-1000. The higher the score, the better the relationship between you and that nation. You typically have stronger relations with countries that share your political ideology. If you have good relations with a nation, it is more likely to join your alliance in a war. If you have poor relations with a nation, it is more likely to join your enemy.
Territorial Transfer
With this treaty you can offer, request, or demand the transfer of regions. Regions will be transferred between your nation and the selected nation.

From the World Market panel, you can request and offer aid. When you offer aid, you agree to give supplies to a nation, without receiving anything in return. However, there are non-monetary benefits to giving aid. Your aid might keep a nation alive or strengthen the relationship between your nations. Similarly, when nations offer you aid, they might have the goal of supporting your nation or improving your alliance.

Your military runs on arms. Without a steady supply of arms, your forces will lose combat strength. When you expand your military, keep in mind the arms your larger forces will require. Arms requirements increase when units are active (in transit or in battle). You can review arms levels in the Supplies panel, and can see active and idle arms requirements in the Book, in Military--Unit Costs.

A city's capacity is how many Industrial Production Units (IPUs) it has per turn. If operating at full capacity--without resource shortages or bombing damage--a city with a capacity of 30 can produce 30 IPUs in a turn. Resource shortages, supply shortages, and military attack can slow production. Cultural differences also keep cities from producing at full capacity.

Industrial production and research take place in cities. The amount of production depends on the city's infrastructure (Preindustrial, Industrial, or Advanced) and IPU capacity.
When MAKING HISTORY starts, your cities might produce a mix of arms, goods, military units, and research. Additionally, cities can invest in expansion and upgrades and port cities can produce Transport Capacity credits and repair naval forces. From your cities, you can set rally points--regions where completed land forces will gather. City production can be damaged by budgetary deficits, lack of supplies and goods, or military attack. Production is also lower in cities that do not share your national culture.
City Production

In the Economy panel, clicking on the (Nation) Industry button takes you to the City Production box. There you can review and revise what your cities are producing. As leader, you decide what is most important to produce, and change orders accordingly. The four tabbed sections--Cities, Output Distribution, Supplies, and Production Report--allow you to assess all aspects of your nation's industrial needs.

You need coal to produce arms, goods, and military units. To increase coal production, you can maximize a coal mine's production or invest in regional transportation infrastructure. You can also buy and sell coal on the World Market.

Your cities, your military, and your citizens demand supplies. Your cities need oil, metals, and coal, your military needs arms, and your citizens need food and goods. If you do not meet these demands, your city production slows down and your military weakens. You can track demands in the City Production panel; from the Economy panel, click on Nation Production, then click on the Supplies tab to see this information.

From the economic policy panel, you can review finances, run production, set trade, and improve regional infrastructure. Your economic choices can determine your industrial, resource, and financial points--three of the four scores that comprise your total World Power score.
Cities lie at the center of your economy. All industrial production and research happen in them. To fuel cities, you need resources. These resources--coal, metals, and oil--are produced in regions. If you need more resources, you can increase regional production, make trades on the World Market, or seek aid from other nations. Your economy needs money to run. You can earn money through domestic and international sales. By balancing these economic elements, your nation can expand and thrive.
When you export resources (coal, oil, and metals), arms, food, or goods, you generate income for your nation. You can sell these supplies directly to countries or offer them on the World Market.
Financial Report
In the Financial Report box, you can view last turn income and spending, and detailed financial information for infrastructure, military, production and trade.
Food Production

Without enough food, worker production suffers. Food is produced by your unskilled workers. It is sold domestically and any surplus can be traded on the World Market.
In region panels, food production figures help you identify your most valuable food-producing regions--and your enemy's most valuable regions. Upgrading regional food production increases production and reduces the MPUs needed to produce food. A region's food production can be damaged by combat in the region.
Expanding your military and maximizing resource production pull MPUs away from food production, reducing output.
Food Revenue
Internal food sales and international food trades generate income for your nation.

Goods keep your workers satisfied and bring you money. When you produce goods, you can sell them to your citizens and trade them on the World Market. These profits strengthen your financial score (important to your overall score) and give you money to spend elsewhere. If workers lack goods, production output suffers. You can review goods levels in the Supplies panel.
Goods Revenue
Producing and selling goods (domestically and on the World Market) generates income for your nation. However, in times of war, military production might take precedence.
Idle Cities

Idle cities do not produce anything. Typically, they are cities in recently acquired regions. They are listed in the Turn Summary panel and, from the city or City Production panel, you can restart production.
Importing resources (coal, oil, and metals) and arms can help you fill production or military shortages. You can buy these supplies off the World Market, or purchase them directly from countries.

Your nation gains income from the domestic purchase of food, the domestic purchase of goods, and from the World Market export of resources, food, goods, and arms. Without income, you will run a deficit, which damages your financial score and your overall World Power score.
Increasing City Production

To increase a city's production rate (IPUs) you must dedicate that city's current production to building industry. The cost of building new IPUs depends on the city's technology level. Each technology level has a maximum IPU value. Once you've reached that value, further investments in building industry will go to upgrading the city's technology level.
Industrial Efficiency

The Industrial Efficiency percentage indicates how well your production orders are being filled. This percentage can be damaged by resource shortages, goods shortages, and bombings. Additionally, regions that don't share your nation's culture will never produce at 100 percent efficiency.

Improving regional infrastructure takes time and money. You should select upgrades depending on your nation's short and long-term production and defensive needs. You can upgrade regional transportation infrastructure, food production, and defensive fortifications. Upgrade individual regions by clicking on them from any map view.
Combat in a region can damage infrastructure. If infrastructure is damaged due to combat, you will be notified in the Turn Summary panel.
To see all your regions at once, from the Economy panel, click on the Infrastructure button. There you can review your regions' capabilities and make improvements to transportation, food production, and fortifications.

You need IPUs (Industrial Production Units) to build everything in the game. All cities have IPUs, with amounts contingent on the city's size and industrial level. A city's IPU number represents its per turn production capacity (i.e. how much it can produce).
Labor Groups

All able-bodied citizens are unskilled workers, skilled workers, soldiers, sailors, or air force cadets. Skilled workers produce arms, goods, and military units. Unskilled workers produce food and can be recruited into the military.
Maintenance, Infrastructure
Infrastructure maintenance is the cost of running your infrastructure and investing in upgrades.

You can increase resource production by +1, you can maximize production or you can invest in transportation infrastructure. When you maximize, you quickly increase production, but at great expense. If you stop maximizing, production returns to its regular rate. Transportation investments take longer to achieve, but they cost less than maximizing and increase production permanently.

You need metals to produce arms, goods, and military units. To increase metals production, you can maximize production in metals foundries or invest in regional transportation infrastructure. You can also buy and sell metals on the World Market.

In MAKING HISTORY, you need money to build your military, purchase goods, develop research, improve city production, and invest in infrastructure. You can have a budget deficit and still run your nation, but this deficit will hurt city production and damage your financial score, which will lower your total World Power score.
In the Economy panel, you can review your finances. The Net Balance number is the difference between National Income and National Spending. The Treasury figure is how much your government has saved--or is in debt.
MPUs are Manpower Units. 1 MPU=1000 workers. A city's or region's MPU number indicates how many workers it has. You need MPUs to produce resources, military units, supplies, and food.
Naval Repairs
You can repair damaged ships in your port cities. First you have to move the ships into port. Then you can switch to repair. Changing to naval repair cancels any projects in progress.

You need oil to produce arms, goods, and military units. To increase oil production, you can maximize oil well production or invest in regional transportation infrastructure. You can also buy and sell oil on the World Market.
Output Distribution
In the City Production panel, the Output Distribution tab shows what production orders are in progress, what cities are assigned to those orders, and when they'll be finished.

Port cities lie adjacent to sea regions. You can build and restore naval forces in your ports. When a naval group is in port, its supply needs are lower. A group in port cannot be seen on the Operational map, but the light in the port city's lighthouse icon will be lit to indicate its presence. Naval forces in port can be bombed.

All production happens in cities. Each city has its own technology level (Preindustrial, Industrial or Advanced) that determines production rates.
Healthy production is essential to game success. Your nation needs arms, goods, and weapons to survive. Production can be damaged by budgetary deficits, lack of supplies and goods, or military attack. Production is also lower in cities that do not share your national culture.
Production Order

Production orders are what your cities build. When MAKING HISTORY starts, your cities might produce a mix of arms, goods, military units, and research. From a city panel or the City Production panel, you can adjust production orders and plan your nation's future. In cities you control, you can: produce arms, goods, or military units; repair naval forces (port cities); develop research or Transport Capacity; or, invest in factory expansion or upgrades.
Production Penalties

A city's IPU output can be penalized by: -- Lack of resources (oil, coal, metals) -- Lack of goods (workers become dissatisfied) -- Aerial bombing and regional combat. Most damage only lasts the duration of the attack, but some attacks can destroy city IPUs.
Production also suffers if a city is controlled by a foreign government (the city culture is not shared by the nation). If you capture a foreign city during a war, it will produce at 50% capacity. When you control a foreign city and are not at war with the city's original owners, the city will produce at 75% capacity. You can view city production losses from individual city panels. You can view overall production losses in the Economy panel.
Production Report

In the City Production box, the Production report summarizes your production of supplies and the completion and deployment of your military units. Clicking on the Production Report button in the Turn Summary panel will take you to City Production.
Regions, Land

Controlling land regions is essential to victory. Regions contain cities (and city production), resource producers, and food producers. If you lose control of regions, you lose the game.
From any map, you can click on any region and see its population, point value, regional culture, and unskilled labor force. You can also see its food production capacity, defensive fortifications, transportation infrastructure, and terrain type.
In your own regions, you can invest in regional infrastructure upgrades: improvements of food production, transportation, and defenses. Note that combat in a region can damage these upgrades. If a region's infrastructure is damaged, you will be notified in the Turn Summary panel.
If you control regions that do not share your national culture(s), they will not produce food or resources at full capacity, and those regions' cities will not produce IPUs at full capacity.
Regions, Sea

You can ship supplies and army units across sea regions. To obtain these materials, you'll need clear transport access from start to destination. No one can own sea regions; your naval groups can pass peacefully through sea regions that contain non-enemy groups. If you share a sea region with an enemy group, you will automatically enter into battle, unless you or your enemy have submarine-only groups. You can blockade an enemy nation by placing your naval groups in crucial sea regions. This will cut off your enemy's access to trade by sea.

Research projects improve your nation's military strength and technological abilities. Projects are long-term investments, and success is not guaranteed. When you complete a research project, you can advance to the next level in that research track. You can click on the Research Projects button to review and set projects.
Note that completed research is blue, available research is white/tan and has a start research button, and research beyond your technology is gray.
You fund research projects by dedicating city IPUs to research. The research effort level shows how many city IPUs you've dedicated to research. The higher the percentage, the better your chance of gaining a research point each turn. You can never reach 100% effort because research success is never that easy.
Each turn, you can gain a point for your research. As you are researching challenging new technologies, you shouldn't expect to gain research points every turn. You can research all projects equally or prioritize specific projects.
You can tell if a project is getting the IPUs it needs by looking at the research report. If the project is green, it is receiving all the IPUs it needs. If it is yellow, then it is receiving less than it needs. If it is red, then the project is receiving no IPUs.
Resource Producers

Oil wells, metals foundries, and coal mines are your resource producers. Run by skilled workers, resource production sites are crucial to your nation's health. You need these resources to produce goods, arms, and military units.
From the Operational map you can click on icons for oil wells, metal foundries, and coal mines. Clicking on them takes you to their resource panels. In resource producer panels you can see output capacity (how much that resource producer can produce), base output rates, transportation bonuses, skilled labor requirements, and maintenance costs.
You can also see the money, time, and labor costs for resource producers. You can increase production by selecting increase or maximizing, or by investing in transportation infrastructure. When you select increase, you increase production by +1. When you maximize, you quickly increase production, but at great expense. When you invest in transportation, it increases production at a lower cost than maximizing, but takes longer to achieve. You can also choose to decrease production by -1 or minimize production.
Skilled Workers
Skilled workers work in city factories, mines, oil wells, and metals foundries. They produce arms, goods, resources, and weapons. Skilled workers need food and goods to produce at full capacity.

Your government spends money on research projects; goods importation; military maintenance; infrastructure and defense improvements; and military units, arms, transport credits, and goods production. If you spend more than you make, then your nation will run a deficit and your financial score will suffer.

When your production or purchase of supplies is greater than your needs, you begin stockpiling. These stockpiles can then be used when your production needs increase or when you lose access to other supply sources. To generate income, you can sell stockpiles on the World Market. Stockpile figures appear at the top of the game screen; they are the numbers to the left of the slash mark.

In the City Production box, the Supply panel shows supply stockpiles, production, trade, and demand. Supplies are Arms, Coal, Goods, Metals, and Oil. They are essential to completing production orders; without them, your nation cannot survive. You can increase your supplies through investments in transportation infrastructure or maximizing resource producer production. You can buy supplies on the World Market or ask for them as aid. Also you can gain supplies through conquest of supply-rich regions. Stockpile and supply rates are constantly at the top of the screen in the Info bar.
Supply Rate

The supply rate is the difference between the demand, trade, and production of a supply. This figure is constantly at the top of your screen in the Info bar. The number to the left of the slash mark is the stockpile, while the number to the right is the supply rate. Supply rates can be seen in greater detail in the City Production panel; click on the Supplies tab, and you can see your rates of production, trade, and demand.
Terrain Type

Every region has a terrain type. This type affects food production and transport infrastructure. Regional infrastructure upgrades cannot change terrain bonuses and penalties; they stay the same throughout the game.
Game terrains are:
-- Plains: Flat lands, good for farming. -- Hills: Areas with a mixture of woods, hills and arable land. Also good for farming. -- Mountains: Easy to defend, and difficult to traverse. -- Desert: Arid land, with little food production and low defenses. -- Jungle: Uncultivated land, difficult to conquer. -- Tundra: Land above the arctic circle. Treeless and cold, with limited food production.

When you sell supplies on the World Market, you do not control the buyers. Any nation you are not at war with can buy your supplies. The same is true when you buy from the World Market; you can purchase supplies from any non-combatant nation.
If you prefer to trade directly with countries, you can. These direct trades allow you to support allies and keep strategic nations well-supplied.
Trade Level
The amount of supplies you are offering or requesting.
Trade Value
The cost (in 1936 US dollars) of the supplies you are offering or requesting.
Transport Capacity

In port cities, you can produce Transport Capacity credits. You need them to send land forces across sea regions. One credit will send one land division to sea. You cannot buy these credits on the World Market; your port cities must produce them. You can view Transport Capacity levels in the top left of the Info bar.
Transportation Infrastructure

Transportation infrastructure can range from 0 (unpaved roads) to 4 (highways and railroads). Transportation upgrades improve resource production; the better your infrastructure, the more you can produce and distribute. Upgrades also increase military forces' speed through a region. Combat in a region can damage infrastructure upgrades.
The money in your treasury is your accumulated income--or your increasing debt. All money in MAKING HISTORY is presented in 1936 dollar values.
Unskilled Workers
Unskilled workers produce food and can be recruited into the military.
Upgrade Industry

In your preindustrial and industrial level production centers, you can upgrade industry. Each upgrade improves the ratio of workers to production and allows you to build more advanced units. This multi-turn process changes preindustrial centers to industrial and upgrades industrial centers to advanced. Upgrading is an expensive process. You can only upgrade to a new level when you've increased a city's IPU level to the upper limit of its current level.
Ratio of workers to production:
-- In preindustrial cities, you need 50 MPUs to produce 1 IPU. -- In industrial cities, you need 20 MPUs to produce 1 IPU. -- In advanced cities, you only need 10 MPUs to produce 1 IPU.
World Market

You can buy, sell, or trade supplies on the World Market. World Market sales of arms, goods, and resources take place during a turn; a supply might disappear before your eyes if another nation purchases it.
If you place a good on the World Market, you cannot choose who buys it. When you buy a good, a seller cannot reject you. However, after a nation buys goods from you on the World Market, you can cancel the trade. Other nations can do the same to you. When you go to war, all trades are canceled between you and your enemies.
Trading on the World Market is a business transaction; buying or selling there has no impact on your diplomatic relations. Only direct trade can improve relations.
World Trade
In the Economy panel, when you click on the World Trade button, the World Market box will appear. There you can review and propose trades and aid.
Alliance Victory

Alliance Victory is one of MAKING HISTORY's Victory Conditions. To win an Alliance Victory game, your alliance must have the most World Power points by the end of the game. You can change alliances throughout the game; it's your alliance on the final turn that matters.
In multiplayer games you can chat with your friends--and your enemies. You can have multiple chats, ranging from one-on-one dialogues to all-nation conversations.

If you have resources and goods, you can produce at full capacity--but only in cities that share your nation's culture. Every city has a culture that represents its region's majority ethnic or national population. Nations can have multiple cultures. If you control regions that do not share your national culture(s), they will not produce food or resources at full capacity, and those regions' cities will not produce IPUs at full capacity.
Decision Points

Decision Points appear after you or other players take action; perhaps you've ended a turn or proposed a treaty. Decision Points force you to make choices. They "lock" the rest of the game (except chat). You cannot do anything until you respond to them.
Diplomatic Map
From this map view, you can see which nations belong to your alliances. Click on the star icon under the mini map to view the Diplomatic map.

In the Domestic panel you can view demographic information, invest in research projects, and liberate nations you've conquered. To view the Domestic panel, click on the column icon in the upper right.
Domination Victory

Before you start a game, you can choose your victory conditions: Alliance, Nation, or Ideology victory. When you choose victory conditions, you can also set the percentage for Domination Victory. For example, if you choose Alliance victory, and set Domination Victory at 50%, when your alliance controls 50% of World Power Points, you win the game.
End Turn

Some game actions are implemented during a turn. For example, treaties are accepted or rejected after you send them. Other game actions, such as military movements, do not happen until you end the turn. Click on the End Turn button at the bottom right of the screen to execute your actions and move to the next turn.
Financial Points
Financial points represent your nation's economic power.

Ideology is a nation's political system. There are four ideology types in MAKING HISTORY. Nations can be Authoritarian, Communist, Democratic, or Fascist. You can choose Ideology Victory as a victory condition before starting the game. Nation ideology changes when, in a peace treaty, a nation agrees to install a friendly government. It also changes when one nation liberates another. The newly-free nation will take its liberator's ideology.
Ideology Map

Every nation in MAKING HISTORY belongs to one of four ideologies: Authoritarian, Communist, Democratic, or Fascist. With the Ideology map you can see which nations share ideologies. You can also click on regions, nations and capital cities.
In Supply Map
From this map you can see what trade routes are open to your nation. Occupied regions and enemy lands are "out of supply". To view the In Supply map, click on the arms icon under the mini map.
Industrial Points
Industrial points represent the strength of your nation's industry. This total includes all regions you conquer and control
Info Bar
At the top of the screen you can see the turn number, turn timer, date, and season, as well as stockpile and supply rate figures.
International Events
In the Turn Summary panel, the International Events list shows what treaties have been signed, wars have been declared, and regions have been transferred or are in conflict.
Keyboard Map Controls

Move North--Up Arrow Move South--Down Arrow Move East--Right Arrow Move West--Left Arrow Tilt Up--Number Pad 8 Tilt Down--Number Pad 2 Zoom In--Number Pad Plus Zoom Out--Number Pad Minus Return to Default--Number Pad 5
Keyboard Shortcuts

You can use keyboard shortcuts to change map views, jump from panel to panel, open pop up boxes, and the log.
CTRL+S Make scoring list appear or disappear. ESC Clear all pop ups, quit any right click menus, deselect any selected objects. CTRL+Q Quit the game. CTRL+L Open and write in the Log
1 Open Operational map view. 2 Open World Summary map view. 3 Open Diplomatic map view. 4 Open Trade map view. 5 Open In Supply map view.
F1 Open Turn Summary panel. F2 Open Military panel. F3 Open Diplomatic panel. F4 Open Domestic panel. F5 Open Economic panel. F6 Open Scoring box. F7 Open Research box. F8 Open Production box F9 Open World Market box. F10 Open Infrastructure box.

In the log, you can take notes on your game. Describe what's happening, what you hope to do, how events compare to history. These writings can be reviewed at any time in the Book. To access the log, click on CTRL+L. To view log entries, go to the Book.
Manpower Points
Manpower points represent the number of workers at your command.

Maps are central to playing Making History. You'll use the Operational map to move forces and review cities, regions, resources, and countries. The secondary maps give you big-picture information on trade and diplomacy. You can click on the icons under the mini-map to access each map view. From the Operational map view, you can click on any city, region, or nation in the game. From other maps, you can click on all regions, countries, and capital cities.
Mini Map

Use the mini map in the upper left corner to quickly move around the world. Clicking anywhere on the mini map will take you immediately to that destination. The controls above the mini map allow you to move in any direction, zoom in and out, tilt up and down, and return to your default map location (your nation). You can also use your mouse or the arrow keys on your number pad to navigate the map. You can open or minimize the mini map by clicking on its arrow icon.
National Events
In the Turn Summary panel, under the National Events heading, you'll find information on production, resource shortages, trade changes, completed research, and industrial upgrades.

There are 80+ countries in MAKING HISTORY. In a nation panel you can see total population (including colonies and conquered regions), labor pool, national culture, world power points, and industrial output. From a nation panel, you can review your diplomatic relations with that nation, send or cancel treaties, declare war, or propose peace.

All major global events appear in 'pop up' notifications. Typically these include declarations of war against your nation and new alliances with your nation. You cannot continue playing MAKING HISTORY until you read a notification and click OK.
Operational Map

The Operational map is essential to playing Making History. From this map, you can move forces and view military forces, battles, cities, regions, countries, and resources. To view the Operational map, click on the crossed swords icon under the mini map.
Resource Points
Resource points represent the oil, coal, and metals produced in your nation and in all regions you conquer and control.
Scoring Points
Found in the land region panel, scoring points are a region's value. This value is determined by the region's population, industrial production, and resources.

As your game advances, the seasons change. Each season has a unique set of values that affect the game. Seasons impact food production rates, transport times, and combat. In particular, winter weather can reduce food production and slow troop movement.
Trade Map
To view the Trade map, click on the ship icon below the mini map. Here you can see which countries you have embargoed. Click on another nation to view its embargos.
Turn Summary

The Turn Summary panel appears automatically after you've ended a turn. During a turn, you can view this panel by clicking on the globe icon.
In the Turn Summary panel, you can review your nation's Victory Conditions, World Power Score, Combat Reports, and National Events. You'll also see all International Events
Victory Conditions

When you meet a scenario's Victory Conditions, you win the game. There are three Victory Condition options: you can acquire the most World Power points, your alliance can acquire the most points, or your ideology can gain the most points. You choose your Victory Condition before beginning the game, and can see your scenario's Victory Conditions in the Turn Summary panel. There you can click on the Victory Conditions button to see score details.
World Power Points

World Power points are crucial to victory in MAKING HISTORY. World Power scores are always on display in the bottom right corner of the map. For more detailed scoring, go to the End of Turn Summary panel (click on the globe icon) and click on Scenario Scoring. All nations are scored on their manpower levels, industrial production, resources, and financial strength.
World Summary Map

To see the World Summary map, click on the flag icon under the mini map. This map gives a big picture view of the world's countries. You can see nation borders and capitals. A conquered region changes to its new ruler's color.
Air attacks on military groups

1. From the Operational map, click on a plane or carrier. A green circle appears to show that it has been selected. That group's information will appear in the right hand panel. 2. Choose the military group you want to bomb. Right click on the group. 3. Choose Bomb from the menu. 4. A red arrow will outline the attack path. 5. If the group you are attacking moves out of the region, your group will stop bombing.
Attack cities and resource producers

1. From the Operational map, click on a bomber plane. A green circle appears to show that it has been selected. That group's information will appear in the right hand panel. 2. Choose the city or resource producer you want to bomb. Right click on that object. 3. A small menu will appear. Choose Bomb. 4. A red arrow will then outline the attack path.
Attack land regions with naval forces

1. Carrier ships' airplanes can attack objects in land regions within aircraft range. Left click on a group that contains at least one carrier ship. 2. Right click on an object (city, military force, or resource producer) in an adjacent land region. 3. Choose Bomb (object).
Attack with naval groups

1. From the Operational map, click on a naval group. A green circle appears to show that it has been selected. That group's information will appear in the right hand panel. 2. Move your group into the region of the foreign group you want to attack. If you are already at war with that nation, your naval group will automatically attack when you end the turn. 3. End the turn. If you are NOT at war with the foreign force, after ending the turn, you have to directly attack. 4. Reselect your group. Right click on the enemy group and choose attack. Air Force

Fighting in groups, air units can attack land and air forces, cities, ships, and resource producers. They can also patrol and perform reconnaissance over land and water, both crucial to unfogging regions. Air units cannot control regions. Look in Military Unit Types in the Book to see air unit capabilities.
Arms Required
Your military runs on arms. Without a steady supply of arms, your units cannot engage in battle. The Arms Required figure indicates how many arms your military needs.

Army units are called primary units because they are the only military forces that can control land regions. Conquering and defending land regions is essential to game success. Army units are called divisions. These divisions fight in groups. A group can contain any combination of Infantry, Armored, Artillery, Missiles, or Mobile divisions.
Within those categories, there are different types of armed divisions. Some are available at the start of the game, others you can develop through research. You can look in Military Unit Types in the Book to see army unit capabilities.

Battles occur between two or more nations. On the Operational map, they appear as explosions. In the mini map, battles are represented as red dots. By clicking on the fiery battle icons, you can see combat reports. These reports contain details about the combatants, their units' strength and their damage. You can only view details for battles that involve you and your allies or are in regions adjacent to your regions. All other battles are fogged.
Bomber Planes
Bombers can travel farther than fighters. They can attack everything fighters can attack, plus naval groups, cities and resource producers.
Carrier Ships
Carrier ships can patrol, support land battles, and attack any land, sea, or air targets. They are the only naval forces that can attack land targets and unfog adjacent sea regions.
Combat Bonuses and Penalties

In the detailed Combat Report you can see combat bonuses and penalties for you and your enemies. Bonuses come from fortifications, tactics (completed tactical research), and terrain. Penalties are from terrain and special operations (ex: amphibious landings).
Combat Power
Combat Power is the strength of a military group. You can click on any group to view its combat power. This allows you to compare your forces' power to an enemy's before engaging in battle.
Combat Report

In a Combat Report you can see how forces are faring in an battle. To view a report, you can either click on an battle icon (an explosion) on the Operational map or you can click on the combat reports listed in the Turn Summary panel. You can only see detailed Combat Reports for battles in unfogged regions--battles that involve you and your allies or are in regions bordering your regions.
In the Turn Summary panel, the combat summaries show the attacking nation's flag on the left and the defending nation's flag on the right. Next to each flag is a set of numbers. The black number shows how many forces remain, and the red number shows how many forces have been lost. When a battle is won, the losing country is grayed out in the combat summary.
The Combat Report shows the remaining and lost forces for each unit type. The left number shows the remaining forces for that unit, the middle number shows the forces lost in the previous turn, and the right number shows the total lost forces.
Escort Destroyers--an advanced level of destroyer--are the only ships that can see submarines.

If you encounter economic difficulties, you might want to disband military groups. This weakens your military (and lowers your military score) but lessens the burden on your treasury (which improves your financial score). You cannot disband a group that is in combat.
Fighter Planes
Fighters are strong in air-to-air combat. They can patrol, support land battles, and attack land groups and resource producers.

In Making History, military forces are fogged. You can see your military forces and your allies' forces, but most of the world lies in shadows. As you can only see enemy forces when they lie nearby, you do not know when an attack might come.
With fogging, you can see: -- Your military units. -- Your allies' units. -- Foreign units in land regions next to regions you control or occupy. -- Foreign units in land regions next to regions your allies control or occupy.
You can only unfog regions when: -- Your airplanes fly over a fogged land or sea region. -- The regions are next to a region containing your carrier ships. Carriers are the only naval forces that can unfog adjacent regions.
Force Maintenance
Force Maintenance is the cost of maintaining your military. To reduce costs, you can reduce the size of your military by disbanding groups.

Fortifications are a region's defensive structures. You can click on any region to see its fortifications. You can invest in your regions' fortifications, improving their defenses. Fortification upgrades start at level 0 and can be upgraded to level 4. A region's fortification upgrades can be damaged by combat in the region.
In a region's panel, there are three values listed under Fortifications. Next to the artillery icon is the number of anti-aircraft shots taken per turn at enemy aircraft. Upgrades increase the number of anti-aircraft shots and increases the odds of a successful hit. The number next to the bunker icon indicates the defensive bonus gained from manmade fortifications (trenches, bunkers, flak towers, etc. . . ) Next to the terrain icon you can see the terrain's defensive bonus. This number indicates the natural advantages of the region. Upgrades do not change this.

A unit is a discrete military force. Your cities produce units. A group is a combination of units. Within a military branch, you can have mixed groups (ex: bombers and fighters) or single-unit divisions (ex: infantry only). Mixed-unit groups bring diverse strengths, while single-unit groups can capitalize on unique unit characteristics. Army units are called divisions, Naval units are ships and flotillas, and Air Force units are squadrons.
Land Divisions
Land divisions are your armed forces. With your army, you can defend and conquer land regions.
If you want fewer, more powerful military groups, you can merge military forces. To combine groups, they must be in the same region. You cannot merge groups that are in combat.

Your military policies can determine whether you succeed or merely survive MAKING HISTORY. Will you build defensive forces, and prepare to protect your borders? Or, will you build an aggressive military and plan attacks?
Your army, navy, and air forces contain a variety of military units, each with a set of offensive and defensive capabilities. Offensive powers are measured in how well a unit can attack on land, in air or at sea. Defensive strength is assessed by how many hits a unit can absorb in battle. Some units have capabilities unique to their unit type. For example, submarines can hide from enemy ships. Only land units can conquer and control territories.
You'll want to develop the units that, when combined, best support your military strategies. To see detailed information about each unit, you can look, in the game, at the Military Unit Type chart in the Book.To view the Military panel, click on the crossed swords icon in the upper right of the screen.
Military Manpower

In the Military panel, the Military Manpower number represents the total population of your army, navy, and air force. Military forces are recruited from the unskilled labor pool, and join the military as you build new units.
Military Units

A city's location and technology level determine the military units it can produce. For example, preindustrial cities cannot produce highly advanced weaponry and naval units can only be built in port cities. To increase a city's military build options, you need to upgrade industry. To increase your overall military build options, you'll want to invest in military research.
Completed land units are, by default, placed in the city's region. You can change this by setting a Rally Point. When you set a Rally Point, newly finished units will automatically travel to that point.

With your naval forces, you can command the seas. Traveling in groups, naval ships and flotillas can patrol sea regions, battle enemy naval forces, blockade ports, and escort transport ships (land divisions moving across water). Sea regions cannot be controlled or owned. Look at Military Unit Types in the Book to see naval unit capabilities.

When you send a plane on patrol, you are preparing it to fight. If an enemy plane enters the patrolled region, it will automatically battle with your plane. You can patrol any region--not just regions you control--but only with fighter planes. You can only patrol in regions adjacent to your base.
Rally Point

Completed land units are, by default, placed in the region where they are produced. You can change this by setting a Rally Point. Finished units move automatically to the Rally Point. This will not happen instantaneously; they will travel to the Rally Point at their usual speed. You can set Rally Points in regions you own or control.
Reconnaissance missions unfog land and sea regions; by sending planes on reconnaissance, you can see where non-allied forces have assembled.
Recruitable Manpower

The Recruitable Manpower number indicates how many unskilled workers you can draft into your military. You can click on the Military button to build military units. New conscripts automatically join the military as you complete new military forces.

Your forces can leave a battle at any time, provided they can retreat to a safe adjacent region. A safe region can be controlled by you or an ally or be an enemy region that doesn't contain enemy forces. If all surrounding regions contain enemy forces, then you cannot retreat.

Splitting military groups allows you to spread your forces across more regions. You can split a group into two groups of equal power, or you can divide power unevenly. You cannot split a group that is in combat.

Submarine-only groups do not automatically attack enemy ships. They are hidden (except from Escort Destroyers) and only attack at your command. When they attack, they become visible. If you move a submarine group into a region containing enemy ships, you can pass through peacefully or choose the attack command.
Supply Level

Arms fuel your military. Without them, your forces weaken. The Supply Level percentage tells you whether you are meeting your arms requirements. You can fail to meet these requirements if you do not purchase or produce enough arms. You can also suffer a supply shortage if your enemies block supply lines to your military.
Transport Ships

When army units move across sea regions, they become transports. Transports have no defenses. To protect them, other ships can serve as escorts. To move army units across the sea, you need one Transport Capacity credit per unit. If you do not have enough credits, your transport ships cannot launch.
Unit Type Categories

Found in the Military section of the book, the Military Unit Types chart lists the basic characteristics of all military units.
Attack--The number of shots the unit has each turn. If successful, each shot does one point of damage.
Hit Points--The hits a unit can take before being destroyed.
Land--The percentage chance the unit has of hitting a land unit.
Air--The percentage chance the unit has of hitting an air unit.
Sea--The percentage chance the unit has of hitting a sea unit.
City--The percentage chance the unit has of hitting a city or a resource producer. A successful hit will cause temporary damage and might lower the city's IPU rate or the resource producer's production rate.
Active--The arms consumed by the unit when active. Land units are active when in transit or battle. Air units are active when rebasing, running a mission, or fighting. Naval units are active whenever they are out of port.
Idle--The arms consumed by the unit when idle.
Speed--The miles per turn the unit can move, with ideal terrain and season conditions.
MPUs--The Manpower Units needed to build the unit.
Maint. Cost--The cost of maintaining the unit.
Range--The distance an air unit can travel from its base.
Fighter HP--The damage a carrier ship's fighter planes can receive.

Wars can begin in several ways. You can declare war (or war can be declared on you); you can attack a nation, which is an act of war (or you can be attacked); or, you can ally with a nation that is at war, and their enemies become your enemies.
